clinical_study.brief_title: Antibodies in Repeated Influenza Vaccination (ARIVA) Study
clinical_study.official_title: Antibodies in Repeated Influenza Vaccination (ARIVA) Study

collaborator.agency: Academisch Medisch Centrum - Universiteit van Amsterdam (AMC-UvA)

brief_summary.textblock:
Viruses with high mutation rates, such influenza or HIV, pose a major challenge for vaccine design. The current influenza vaccination strategy of yearly vaccination with adapted strains aims to maximally diversify the antibody immune response to prevent viral escape. There is, however, growing evidence, that repeated vaccination with very similar viral proteins might limit, instead of broaden, diversification and thereby reduce vaccine efficacy.
The ARIVA Study prospectively studies the immunological impact of repeated influenza vaccination on viral variant recognition and antibody responses in healthy subjects cross-sectionally and over three consecutive vaccination seasons.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change between baseline and 28 days post-vaccination will be compared
primary_outcome.description: Hemagglutination titers against different H3N2 Influenza strains will be measured and compared between study subjects stratified by number of previous vaccinations

secondary_outcome.description: Frequency of plasmablasts in the peripheral blood will be assessed and compared between study subjects stratified by number of previous vaccinations

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Cross sectional comparison of the BCR repertoire characteristics day 0 and day 28
secondary_outcome.description: Sorted B cell subsets will be sequenced to define the BCR repertoire. Subjects will be compared stratified by vaccination status

intervention.description: Only subjects vaccinated against influenza will be enrolled. The study itself is observational

biospec_descr.textblock: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells, serum and RNA is collected

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- influenza vaccination (QIIV) independent of the study
- age >18 yo
Exclusion Criteria:
- no vaccination
- current acute illness
